trustZone.name: Private Secured
trustZone.desc: A secured zone within a trusted private zone

dataflow.name: s3 VPC Endpoints -> Public / Accelerate End Point (HTTP/S)
S3 Control Public Endpoint (HTTP/S) -> S3 Control
AWS Services (Compatible with Access Point) -> Access Point (Internal)
s3 VPC Endpoints -> Multi-Region Access Point
AWS Services (with/without IAM) -> Public / Accelerate End Point (HTTP/S)
s3 VPC Endpoints -> Public End Point

weakness.name: Unlimited/MOnitored access via S3 VPC Endpoints

countermeasure.name: S3 VPC Endpoints covered by VPC endpoint controls
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all S3 VPC endpoints (Interface and Gateway) are covered by the VPC endpoints controls

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring all S3 VPC endpoints (Interface and Gateway) are covered by the VPC endpoints controls, and its records

threat.name: Exfiltrate data via ungoverned S3 endpoint
threat.desc:
S3 VPC endpoints can be either Interface or Gateway. An attacker can create a second endpoint to create an ungoverned exfiltration vector.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "ec2:CreateVpcEndpoint"

}

weakness.name: Block all requests not using SigV4

countermeasure.name: Block all requests not using SigV4
countermeasure.desc: Block all requests not using SigV4 (e.g. using an SCP and S3 policy on all buckets with deny on "StringNotEquals":{"s3:signatureversion": "AWS4-HMAC- SHA256"})

test.steps: Make a non-SigV4 AWS API call, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Block deprecated S3 actions, using IAM ThreatModel and the S3 actions list.
countermeasure.desc: Block deprecated S3 actions, using IAM ThreatModel and the S3 actions list.

test.steps: Request the controls blocking deprecated S3 actions

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events
countermeasure.desc: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events in relevant AWS accounts, Regions and buckets (e.g. production, with sensitive data, etc.). Make it available for security analysis, and protect it using CloudTrail ThreatModel

test.steps: Request the CloudTrail ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling and protecting S3 data events

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Monitor and investigate that all requests not using SigV4
countermeasure.desc: Monitor and investigate that all requests not using SigV4 (e.g via CloudTrail S3 with the additionalEventData.SignatureVersion different from "SigV4")

test.steps: Make a non-SigV4 AWS API call, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Monitor S3 connection
countermeasure.desc: Monitor that all S3 connections are made with virtual-hosted model (e.g via CloudTrail S3 requestParameters.Host)

test.steps: Make a path-style request to S3, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Use SDK with SigV4 enabled
countermeasure.desc: Use SDK with SigV4 enabled (ref)

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring the use of SDK with SigV4 enabled

countermeasure.name: use virtual-hosted model when connecting to S3 endpoints
countermeasure.desc: When connecting to S3 endpoints, use virtual-hosted model ("my-bucket-name.s3.amazonaws.com" or "my-bucket- name.my-s3-regional-endpoint.amazonaws.com") instead of path-style model ("s3.amazonaws.com/my-bucket-name" or "my-s3-regional-endpoint.amazonaws.com/my-bucket-name") (see ref). All the latest SDK make use of domain style, by default.

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring the usage of domain style Very instead of path style.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

threat.name: Use of less secure or old S3 features
threat.desc:
S3 was launched in 2006, and its features have evolved. An attacker can use older features that have been proven less secure by AWS (e.g. certain API configuration, SigV2, path-style model), but are still maintained for retro- compatibility.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:deprecated"

}

weakness.name: Unauthorised AWS accounts Accessing KMS Keys
Unlimited/MOnitored access via S3 VPC Endpoints

countermeasure.name: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key (e.g. using an SCP, bucket policy and VPC endpoint deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not a KMS key from an authorized AWS accounts)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with a KMS key from unauthorized AWS account, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events
countermeasure.desc: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events in relevant AWS accounts, Regions and buckets (e.g. production, with sensitive data, etc.). Make it available for security analysis, and protect it using CloudTrail ThreatModel

test.steps: Request the CloudTrail ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling and protecting S3 data events

countermeasure.name: Limit access to only authorised S3 bucket
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to only authorized S3 bucket(s) or their AWS account(s) from each VPC (e.g. using the condition key "s3:ResourceAccount" on the VPC endpoint policy, alternatively use specific resource-level statement for each bucket, or if the VPC endpoint policy size is beyond the limit and more granular control on VPC is required, use access points)

test.steps: Make a request to an unauthorized bucket from one of your VPC, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account

test.steps: Request the list of authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain list of authorised S3 and S3 Access points
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized S3 and S3 access point (and their respective AWS accounts) to be access for each VPC

test.steps: Request the list of authorized S3 and S3 access point to be access for each VPC, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Monitor VPC DNS query log
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C21,S3.C22]

Monitor VPC DNS query logs that only authorised S3 bucket and S3 access points are being queried in each VPC (e.g. using VPC DNS query logging), and protect it using Route53 ThreatModel

test.steps: Make a DNS query to an unauthorized 1) S3 bucket and 2) S3 access points, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Request access via S3 access point
countermeasure.desc: Request access via S3 access point on bucket you don't own, if compatible with your interaction with the bucket (e.g. not through not-compatible AWS service)

test.steps: Request the documented reason access point was not implemented in the use case

countermeasure.name: Track all buckets you do not control that host your objects
countermeasure.desc: Track all buckets you don't control hosting your objects, define their authorised data classification, identify their respective owners (and AWS account ID), their ObjectACL requirements (including S3 Object Ownership), and get assured for the protection (e.g. through contractual agreement, verified by assurance programs, or using this ThreatModel).

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify that all VPC are limited to authorised S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc: Verify all VPC are limited to limit access to only authorized S3 bucket(s)

test.steps: Remove the control limiting access to only authorized S3 bucket(s), it should be detected.

threat.name: Exfiltrate data by using a S3 VPC endpoint to upload data to an attacker bucket using an internal IAM entity
threat.desc:
VPC endpoints for S3 allow IAM entities to connect from a VPC to any S3 bucket without Internet Gateway. An attacker can exfiltrate pre-collected data to an external S3 bucket via a VPC endpoint, using an internal IAM entity they control. If the attacker does not control object ACL, it can use the name of objects (1KB).

IAM Access

{

"AND": ["s3:PutObject", {

"OPTIONAL": "s3:PutObjectAcl" }]

}

weakness.name: Block Bucket ACL except for server access logging
Changes to make an object public via object ACL
Control where the inventory is stored
Deploy only authorized S3 website and behind a CDN
Have a process to apply a legal hold
Identify and ensure the protection all internal buckets hosting your objects
Limit access from only authorized VPCs
Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats
Restrict access point access to VPC when in use
Unauthorised AWS accounts Accessing KMS Keys
Unlimited/MOnitored access via S3 VPC Endpoints
Use S3 Object Lock to protect data integrity

countermeasure.name: Aligned with your data governance
countermeasure.desc: Aligned with your data governance, encrypt on the client side - or tokenize - appropriate data

test.steps: Request the governance and mechanism(s) used to protect data (e.g. encrypt or tokenize critical data on the client side

countermeasure.name: Backup primary data in a secure location under a different security authority
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C58]

Backup primary data in a secure location under a different security authority (e.g. in an AWS data bunker account via replication)

test.steps: Request the mechanism used to backup primary data in a location which have different security authority, its records of execution, and records of restoration testing

countermeasure.name: Block object access to S3 bucket not via an AP
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C104]
Block any object-related operations access to S3 bucket not through access point (i.e. using a deny IAM policy statement with the condition "ArnNotLike" {"s3:DataAccessPointArn": "arn:aws:s3:Region:AccountId:accesspoint/*"})

test.steps: Access any S3 bucket using the S3 public endpoint, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Block PutObject and PutObjectRetention requests with unauthorized S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C58, assured by S3.C77]
Block PutObject and PutObjectRetention requests with unauthorized S3 Object Lock on each bucket (e.g. using an S3 bucket policy deny statement on PutObject and PutObjectRetention if the condition if exists "s3:object-lock- mode" and "s3:object-lock-remaining-retention-days" is not the defined S3 Object Lock configuration)

countermeasure.name: Block PutObject requests with unauthorized KMS key on each bucket
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C61, assured by S3.C67]
Block PutObject requests with unauthorized KMS key on each bucket (e.g. using an S3 bucket policy deny statement on PutObject if the condition if exists "s3:x-amz-server-side- encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not an authorized KMS key)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with an unauthorized KMS key, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key (e.g. using an SCP, bucket policy and VPC endpoint deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not a KMS key from an authorized AWS accounts)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with a KMS key from unauthorized AWS account, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Block S3 endpoints in your corporate perimeter security to the Internet
countermeasure.desc:
Block S3 endpoints (DNS and IP ranges) in your corporate perimeter security to the Internet (e.g. firewalls, or cloud interception proxy like Kivera) including via Internet Gateway, to force usage of VPC endpoints. It will block data-plane transfer.

Note: AWS console stays functional as it proxies non- data-plane requests (via "console.aws.amazon.com").

countermeasure.name: Block the action "s3:DeleteBucket"
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C39]

Block the action "s3:DeleteBucket" (e.g. via SCP, exemption can be managed by authorizing a SuperAdmin to delete buckets with a certain tag, and with bucket owners able to tag bucket)

test.steps: Do a DeleteBucket, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: block Unauthorised IAM entity
countermeasure.desc: Block any IAM entity not belonging to an authorized AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s) to call S3 from your VPCs by adding a deny statement on S3 VPC endpoint policy of each VPC, with the condition using "aws:PrincipalOrgPaths" (ref) including the full Org ID, as those are globally unique.

test.steps: For each VPC, do an API call with an IAM entity which is not part of its authorized AWS Organizations path(s), it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Create and maintain a list of authorised IAM principals
countermeasure.desc: For each bucket, maintain a list of authorised IAM principals allowed to access via bucket policy

test.steps: Request the list of authorized a list of authorized IAM principals allowed to access via bucket policy, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Create a process to apply legal hold to any S3 bucket
countermeasure.desc: Create a process to apply legal hold to any S3 bucket, whenever required. The condition "s3:object-lock-legal-hold" can be used to restrict who can remove such a lock.

test.steps: Request the process of applying legal hold, and its records

countermeasure.name: Deny requests to add bucket ACL other than for server access logging
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C57]
Deny requests to add bucket ACL other than for server access logging (e.g. using an SCP, bucket policy and VPC endpoint policy blocking PutBucketAcl for all but the following predefined group "http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/s3/LogDelivery" using the IAM condition x-amz-acl: "log-delivery-write")

test.steps: Make a call to create a bucket ACL other than server access logging, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Deny requests to change object ACL to public
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C36]
Deny requests to change object ACL to public (e.g. using an SCP, S3 bucket policy and VPC endpoint policy blocking PutObjectAcl for "s3:x-amz-grant-read", "s3:x-amz-grant- read-acp", "s3:x-amz-grant-write-acp", "s3:x-amz-grant-full- control" on the following predefined groups "http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/AllUsers" and "http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/AuthenticatedUsers")

test.steps: Make a call to create a public ObjectACL, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Do not include sensitive data when naming objects
countermeasure.desc: Do not include sensitive data in bucket names, access point names, object names, object metadata and tags.

test.steps: Request the process ensuring no sensitive data is included in bucket names, object names, object metadata and tags.

countermeasure.name: Enable account-level S3 Block Public Access on all AWS accounts
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C50]
Enable account-level S3 Block Public Access on all AWS accounts, with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true.

test.steps:
1. Create a public bucket and try to access one of its objects without proper authentication

  2. or change the ACL of an existing object to public

the action should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events
countermeasure.desc: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events in relevant AWS accounts, Regions and buckets (e.g. production, with sensitive data, etc.). Make it available for security analysis, and protect it using CloudTrail ThreatModel

test.steps: Request the CloudTrail ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling and protecting S3 data events

countermeasure.name: Enable GuardDuty Monitoring
countermeasure.desc: Enable and monitor S3 protection in Amazon GuardDuty in all AWS accounts in all Regions, and protect it using GuardDuty ThreatModel. Ensure findings are investigated (e.g. using Amazon Detective).

test.steps: Request the GuardDuty ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling, monitoring, investigation and protecting S3 protection

countermeasure.name: Enable Macie
countermeasure.desc: Enable S3 policy findings in Amazon Macie in all AWS accounts in all Regions, and protect it using Macie ThreatModel

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 Block Public Access on all S3 access points
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C54]
Enable S3 Block Public Access on all S3 access points (including multi-region), with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true.

test.steps:
1. Create a public bucket and try to access via access point one of its objects without proper authentication (ref)

  2. change the ACL of an existing object to public and try to access via access point one of its objects

they should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 Block Public Access on all S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C52]
Enable S3 Block Public Access on all S3 buckets, with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true.

test.steps:
1. Create a public bucket and try to access one of its objects without proper authentication


  2. change the ACL of an existing object to public


it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Enable versioning on buckets holding primary data
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C58, assured by S3.C70]
Enable versioning on buckets holding primary data

test.steps: Request the mechanism used to ensure versioning on buckets Very S3.FC5 holding primary data, and its records Low

countermeasure.name: Ensure all objects on S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C62]

Ensure all objects on S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key

test.steps: Request the mechanism (including training, or utility) ensuring only authorized KMS key are used for any objects stored in S3

countermeasure.name: Ensure all S3 buckets interacted with are in the correct AWS account
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all S3 buckets interacted with are in the correct AWS account (e.g. using the condition in all compatible S3 requests: x-amz-expected-bucket-owner and x-amz-source-expected- bucket-owner)

countermeasure.name: Ensure bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C154]
Ensure bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism ensuring bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket
  2. its records of execution for all new buckets
  3. plan to move any older buckets

countermeasure.name: Ensure only authorized buckets are configured as website
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C141, assured by S3.C143]
Ensure only authorized buckets are configured as website

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism ensuring only authorized buckets are configured as website
  2. its records of execution for all new website-enabled buckets
  3. plan to move any older website-enabled buckets

countermeasure.name: Ensure only authorized buckets have replication enabled
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C86, assured by S3.C87,S3.C88,S3.C117]
Ensure only authorized buckets have replication enabled and with correct configuration are configured

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism ensuring only authorized buckets have replication enabled and with correct configuration are configured
  2. its records of execution for all new buckets
  3. plan to move any older buckets

countermeasure.name: Ensure only authorized CloudFront distributions are associated with their authorized bucket, and vice versa
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C101, assured by S3.C102]
Ensure only authorized CloudFront distributions are associated with their authorized bucket, and vice versa.

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism ensuring only authorized only authorized CloudFront distribution are associated with their authorized bucket, and vice versa
  2. its records of execution for all new CloudFront distribution
  3. plan to move any older CloudFront distribution

countermeasure.name: Ensure only authorized IAM roles are attached for each replication
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C89, assured by S3.C92]
Ensure only authorized IAM roles are attached for each replication, ideally dedicated

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring authorized IAM roles are attached for each replication, and the evidence of its execution for all replication configuration

countermeasure.name: Ensure only authorized notification receiver(s) are configured
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C94, assured by S3.C95]
Ensure only authorized notification receiver(s) (e.g. SNS Topic, Lambda, etc.) for each bucket are configured

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism ensuring only authorized notification receiver(s) (e.g. SNS Topic, Lambda, etc.) for each bucket are configured
  2. its records of execution for all new buckets
  3. plan to move any older buckets

countermeasure.name: Ensure only authorized S3 buckets are configured to receive S3 inventory
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C96, assured by S3.C97]
Ensure only authorized S3 buckets are configured to receive S3 inventory for each bucket

test.steps:
Request
  1. the mechanism ensuring only authorized S3 buckets are configured to receive S3 inventory for each bucket
  2. its records of execution for all new buckets
  3. plan to move any older buckets

countermeasure.name: Ensure S3 websites are protected with HTTP headers using a CDN
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C141]
Ensure S3 websites are protected with HTTP headers (ref) using a CDN (e.g. CloudFront)

countermeasure.name: For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, block PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C145, assured by S3.C147]
For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, block PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption (e.g. using an S3 bucket policy deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer- algorithm"="AES265" is not present)

test.steps: Make a request to a bucket (or path) requiring SSE-C without the proper encryption, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, monitor that only authorized encryption
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C145]


For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, monitor that only authorized encryption is used on each bucket or path (using CloudTrail S3 data events in requestParameter.bucketName and response.x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer- algorithm)

test.steps: Make a request to a bucket (or path) requiring SSE-C without the proper encryption, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, verify all buckets block PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption
countermeasure.desc: For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, verify all buckets block PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption

test.steps: Create a bucket requiring SSE-C not blocking PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: For each S3 bucket, maintain a list of VPC(s), authorized to access it.
countermeasure.desc: For each S3 bucket, maintain a list of VPC(s), authorized to access it.

test.steps: For each S3 bucket, request the list of authorized VPC to access it, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Implement an authorized default encryption key
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C61, assured by S3.C65]
Implement an authorized default encryption key on each bucket and enable S3 Bucket Key (note: Amazon S3 evaluates and applies bucket policies before applying bucket default encryption settings)

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism implementing an authorized default encryption key on each bucket and enabling S3 Bucket Key
  2. its records of execution for all new buckets
  3. plan to move any older buckets

countermeasure.name: Implement lifecycle policy to remove incomplete multipart uploads
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C79]
Reduce costs related to incomplete multipart upload by creating a lifecycle policy to remove them after an agreed length of time (e.g. 7 days) (blog)

test.steps: Create an incomplete upload, and wait for the agreed time, it should be deleted automatically.

countermeasure.name: Implement the authorized default S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C58, assured by S3.C75]
Implement the authorized default S3 Object Lock on each bucket (note: Amazon S3 evaluates and applies bucket policies before applying bucket default S3 Object Lock settings)

test.steps: Upload an object without appropriate S3 Object Lock, it should have the S3 Object Lock automatically.

countermeasure.name: Limit access to authorized IAM roles used for replication
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C89]
Limit access to authorized IAM roles used for replication, using the IAM ThreatModel (e.g. trust policy, and "iam:PassRole"

test.steps: Request the IAM ThreatModel and the evidence of its application to the IAM roles used for replication

countermeasure.name: Limit access to only authorised S3 bucket
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to only authorized S3 bucket(s) or their AWS account(s) from each VPC (e.g. using the condition key "s3:ResourceAccount" on the VPC endpoint policy, alternatively use specific resource-level statement for each bucket, or if the VPC endpoint policy size is beyond the limit and more granular control on VPC is required, use access points)

test.steps: Make a request to an unauthorized bucket from one of your VPC, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Limit access via the S3 access point
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C104, assured by S3.C109]
Limit access via the S3 access point by using in VPC endpoint and/or bucket policy the condition "s3:DataAccessPointAccount" or preferably "s3:DataAccessPointArn" in an allow statement to reduce the length of allowlist bucket name in VPC endpoint/bucket policy.

test.steps: Do a request on an unauthorized access point or bucket, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to authorised VPC
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C98, assured by S3.C100]
Limit the access to only those VPC(s) (e.g. using S3 bucket statement, deny if the condition "aws:SourceVpce", or if the bucket policy size is beyond the limit, use this condition on access point)

test.steps: Make a request to the bucket outside an authorized VPC, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Limit the S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C89]
Limit the S3 access to the source/destination bucket and replication rights of each authorized IAM role configured for replication

test.steps: Request the S3 access of replication role, and how they aligned to the replication requirements

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized access between VPC, S3 access point and S3.
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized access between VPC, S3 access point and S3.

test.steps: Request the list of authorized access between VPC and S3 access point

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account

test.steps: Request the list of authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized buckets to be configured as website
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized buckets to be configured as website

test.steps: Request the list of authorized buckets to be configured as website, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized buckets to have replication enabled
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized buckets to have replication enabled, their target bucket and replication type (i.e. ownership, RTC, etc.) (ref).

test.steps: Request the list of authorized buckets to have replication enabled, their target bucket and replication rights, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized CloudFront distribution and associated bucket
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized CloudFront distribution (via origin access identity) and associated bucket

test.steps: Request the list of all authorized CloudFront distribution and associated S3 buckets

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized KMS key(s) for each bucket,
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized KMS key(s) for each bucket, and their default encryption key. You might simplify by using only 1 key per bucket, ideally dedicated. Note that S3 server access log bucket does not support KMS encryption (ref).

test.steps: Request the list of authorized KMS key(s) for each bucket, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized notification receiver(
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized notification receiver(s) (e.g. SNS Topic, Lambda, etc.) for each bucket. You might use a simpler approach by using authorized account ID(s) to ensure all your receivers are in authorized AWS account(s).

test.steps: Request the list of authorized notification receiver (e.g. SNS Topic, Lambda, etc.) for each bucket, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized S3 buckets to receive S3 inventory of each bucket
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized S3 buckets to receive S3 inventory of each bucket

test.steps: Request the list of authorized bucket(s) to receive S3 inventory of each bucket, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of buckets
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of buckets (or paths) required to be encrypted with server-side encryption with customer- provided keys (SSE-C)

test.steps: Request the list of buckets (or paths) required to be encrypted with server-side encryption with customer- provided keys (SSE-C), its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of IAM roles used for replication
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of IAM roles used for replication, ideally dedicated (e.g. using change management process on infrastructure-as-code)

test.steps: Request the list of all IAM roles configured for replication

countermeasure.name: Maintain comprehensive list of those accessing S3
countermeasure.desc: For each VPC, maintain a list of AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s), where IAM entities are authorized to access S3

test.steps: For each VPC, request the list of AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s), where IAM entities are authorized to access S3, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain list of authorised S3 and S3 Access points
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized S3 and S3 access point (and their respective AWS accounts) to be access for each VPC

test.steps: Request the list of authorized S3 and S3 access point to be access for each VPC, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Monitor abnormal behaviour on replication
countermeasure.desc: Monitor abnormal behaviour on replication CloudWatch metrics (i.e. BytesPendingReplication and OperationsPendingReplication)

countermeasure.name: Monitor and investigate anonymous requests to objects
countermeasure.desc: Monitor and investigate anonymous requests to objects (e.g. using CloudTrail S3 data events with userIdentity.accountId=ANONYMOUS_PRINCIPAL)

test.steps: Make an anonymous call, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Monitor changes on bucket ACL
countermeasure.desc: Monitor changes on bucket ACL other than for server access logging (e.g. using CloudTrail, 1) if the CloudTrail PutBucketAcl log indicates requestParameters.AccessControlPolicy.AccessControlList.G rant[].Grantee.xsi:type: "Group", then the URI should be "http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/s3/LogDelivery", and 2) if the requestParameters.AccessControlPolicy.AccessControlList.G rant[].Grantee.xsi:type: "CanonicalUser" then the ID should be the same than "AccessControlPolicy.Owner.ID", and 3) requestParameters.x-amz-acl should be either "private", "log-delivery-write" or not existing)

test.steps: Make a call to create a bucket ACL other than server access logging, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Monitor external buckets to ensure only those authorised are used
countermeasure.desc: Monitor that only authorised external buckets are used (e.g. via CloudTrail S3 data events in resources[].accountId and resources[].ARN). Both account ID and bucket name must be verified.

test.steps: Make a call to an unauthorized bucket, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Monitor ObjectACL change
countermeasure.desc: Monitor ObjectACL changed (or tentatively changed) to public using CloudTrail S3 data events

test.steps: Make a call to create a public ObjectACL, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Monitor that only authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C31]
Monitor that only authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account (using CloudTrail S3 data events in response.x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms- key-id)

test.steps: Make a call to an unauthorized bucket, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Monitor that only authorized KMS key(s) are used on each bucket
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C61]
Monitor that only authorized KMS key(s) are used on each bucket (using CloudTrail S3 data events in requestParameter.bucketName and response.x-amz-server- side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with an unauthorized KMS key, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Monitor VPC DNS query log
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C21,S3.C22]

Monitor VPC DNS query logs that only authorised S3 bucket and S3 access points are being queried in each VPC (e.g. using VPC DNS query logging), and protect it using Route53 ThreatModel

test.steps: Make a DNS query to an unauthorized 1) S3 bucket and 2) S3 access points, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Only Authorised IAM principals allowed
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C149, assured by S3.C151]
Ensure only authorized a list of authorized IAM principals allowed to access via bucket policy are configured (e.g. using IAM Access Analyzer for the reconciliation)

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism ensuring only authorized IAM principals allowed to access via bucket policy are configured
  2. its records of execution for all new buckets
  3. plan to move any older buckets

countermeasure.name: Parameterize S3 bucket name or S3 access point in your code (no hardcoding)
countermeasure.desc: Parameterize S3 bucket name or S3 access point in your code (no hardcoding)

test.steps: Request the process on ensuring S3 bucket name or S3 access point are not hard-coded

countermeasure.name: Prevent the creation of buckets with ACL enabled
countermeasure.desc:
Prevent the creation of buckets with ACL enabled (e.g. by using a SCP and/or an IAM policy on "s3:CreateBucket" with a deny statement on "s3:x-amz-object- ownership":"BucketOwnerEnforced").

Note it does not block someone to enable ACL afterwards via PutPutBucketOwnershipControls.

test.steps: Create a bucket to enable ACL, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Protect Buckets Required to be public
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C48]
Front buckets required to be public, using authenticated CDN (e.g. CloudFront) or API Gateway, protected with WAF (e.g. for hotlinking)

test.steps: Request the process ensuring that buckets required to be public are front by authenticated CDN or API Gateway

countermeasure.name: S3 VPC Endpoints covered by VPC endpoint controls
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all S3 VPC endpoints (Interface and Gateway) are covered by the VPC endpoints controls

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring all S3 VPC endpoints (Interface and Gateway) are covered by the VPC endpoints controls, and its records

countermeasure.name: Scan all data uploaded to external buckets
countermeasure.desc: Scan all data before uploading to an external bucket to ensure the classification of the data is aligned with the bucket classification (e.g. using Macie).

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism ensuring all data are scanned for proper data classification before upload to an external bucket are configured
  2. its records of execution for all object upload flows
  3. plan to move any older object upload flows

countermeasure.name: scan the objects for malware
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C58]
If the bucket is used as an input or the output of a process, scan the objects for malware (e.g. using VirusScan or Trend Micro Cloud One)

test.steps: Inject a malware test file, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Scan your CNAME records
countermeasure.desc: Scan your CNAME records (e.g. in Route53) and CloudFront origin for deleted buckets

countermeasure.name: Secure with VPC Threat Model
countermeasure.desc: For each VPC with an IAM entity allowed to use S3, secure them with the VPC ThreatModel (e.g. modification of VPC endpoints, VPC endpoint policy, routing table, Security Groups)

countermeasure.name: Track all buckets you control and define data classification
countermeasure.desc: Track all buckets you control, define their authorized data classification, identify whether the hosted data is primary (i.e. source of truth, for example logs, backups, forensic data, raw data, etc.) or an input/output of a process (e.g. file-processing, software package, etc.), their WORM requirements (e.g. SEC 17a-4, CTCC, etc.), if they are production/non-production (preferably done at account-level), their storage class. You may use tags, Infra-as-code, AWS Glue Data Catalog or external management tool like FINRA herd)

test.steps: Request the list of all buckets you control, define their authorized data classification, identify whether the data is primary and the mechanism and records to ensure the accuracy of those metadata

countermeasure.name: Track all buckets you do not control that host your objects
countermeasure.desc: Track all buckets you don't control hosting your objects, define their authorised data classification, identify their respective owners (and AWS account ID), their ObjectACL requirements (including S3 Object Ownership), and get assured for the protection (e.g. through contractual agreement, verified by assurance programs, or using this ThreatModel).

countermeasure.name: Use a data discovery tool
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C58]
Use a data discovery tool (e.g. Amazon Macie) to control that no sensitive data are stored in unauthorized bucket

test.steps: Upload a higher classification data in a bucket, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Use a data discovery tool to ensure bucket names
countermeasure.desc: Use a data discovery tool (e.g. Amazon Macie) to ensure the bucket names, object names, tags and metadata do not contain sensitive data

test.steps: Create a bucket name, object name, tags, or a metadata of an object with sensitive data, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Use KMS ThreatModel to protect the KMS keys used for S3
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C61]
Use KMS ThreatModel to protect the KMS keys used for S3 (e.g. using encryptionContext on the policy of each KMS key)

test.steps: Request the KMS ThreatModel and the evidence of its application to protect S3

countermeasure.name: Verify account-level S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all AWS accounts
countermeasure.desc: Verify account-level S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all AWS accounts, with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true (e.g. using the AWS Config rule: S3_ACCOUNT_LEVEL_PUBLIC_ACCESS_BLOCKS).

countermeasure.name: Verify a lifecycle policy on incomplete multipart uploads
countermeasure.desc: Verify a lifecycle policy on incomplete multipart uploads is implemented on all buckets

test.steps: <font size="4">Create a bucket without a lifecycle policy to remove incomplete multipart upload, it should be detected</font>

countermeasure.name: Verify all associations of CloudFront distributions with buckets are authorized
countermeasure.desc: Verify all associations of CloudFront distributions with buckets are authorized

test.steps: Create a non-authorized distribution or association, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all buckets block PutObject requests with an unauthorized KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Verify all buckets block PutObject requests with an unauthorized KMS key (e.g. using the Config rule: S3_BUCKET_POLICY_NOT_MORE_PERMISSIVE, note that a new rule needs be deployed for each configuration, then the resource tracked by name or tag; alternatively you might use S3_BUCKET_SERVER_SIDE_ENCRYPTION_ENABLED to ensure a limited coverage)

test.steps: Create a bucket not blocking PutObject requests with an unauthorized KMS key, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all buckets blocks PutObject and PutObjectRetention requests with unauthorized S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc: Verify all buckets blocks PutObject and PutObjectRetention requests with unauthorized S3 Object Lock (e.g. using the Config rule: S3_BUCKET_POLICY_NOT_MORE_PERMISSIVE, note that a new rule needs be deployed for each configuration, then the resource tracked by name or tag)

countermeasure.name: Verify all buckets have the correct default S3 Object Lock configuration
countermeasure.desc: Verify all buckets have the correct default S3 Object Lock configuration

test.steps:
Create a bucket either

  1. without S3 Object Lock
  2. with an incorrect default S3 Object Lock
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all buckets include a control to limit access to only authorized VPC(s)
countermeasure.desc: Verify all buckets include a control to limit access to only authorized VPC(s) (e.g. using the AWS Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK)

test.steps: Remove the control limiting access to only authorized VPC(s), it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all objects on S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Verify all objects on S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key (e.g. using S3 inventory, see blog, or S3 Storage Lens)

test.steps: Upload an encrypted data using an unauthorized KMS key, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all replicated buckets have metrics enabled on each replication rule
countermeasure.desc: Verify all replicated buckets have metrics enabled on each replication rule (included by default in S3 RTC)

test.steps: Modify the replication metric of an authorized replication, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 access points are VPC attached
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 access points are VPC attached

test.steps: Create an internet-based access point, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify Authorised IAM principals Access
countermeasure.desc: Verify only authorised IAM principals allowed to access via bucket policy are used (e.g. using the AWS Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK)

countermeasure.name: Verify authorized buckets have the correct replication configuration
countermeasure.desc: Verify authorized buckets have the correct replication configuration

countermeasure.name: Verify bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket
countermeasure.desc: Verify bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket

test.steps: Create/modify a bucket to enable ACL, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify buckets holding primary data are versioned
countermeasure.desc: Verify buckets holding primary data are versioned (e.g. using S3_BUCKET_VERSIONING_ENABLED)

test.steps: Remove versioning from a bucket holding primary data, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Verify each bucket has an authorized default encryption key and has S3 Bucket Key enabled
countermeasure.desc: Verify each bucket has an authorized default encryption key and has S3 Bucket Key enabled

test.steps:
Create/modify a bucket

  1. without default encryption
  2. with a wrong default encryption key
  3. or without S3 Bucket Key disabled,

it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify only access points are used in the resource-level statement in VPC endpoints
countermeasure.desc: Verify only access points are used in the resource-level statement in VPC endpoints

test.steps: Create a VPC endpoint giving access to an S3 bucket, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify only authorized buckets are configured as website
countermeasure.desc: Verify only authorized buckets are configured as website

test.steps: Enable website configuration on an unauthorized bucket, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify only authorized buckets are configured to receive inventory.
countermeasure.desc: Verify only authorized buckets are configured to receive inventory.

test.steps: Create an unauthorized bucket to receive inventory, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Verify only authorized buckets have replication enabled and with correct configuration
countermeasure.desc: Verify only authorized buckets have replication enabled and with correct configuration

test.steps: Configure replication on a non-authorized bucket, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Verify only authorized notification receiver(s) are configured for buckets.
countermeasure.desc: Verify only authorized notification receiver(s) are configured for buckets.

test.steps: Create an unauthorized receiver, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify only the authorized IAM role is configured for each replication
countermeasure.desc: Verify only the authorized IAM role is configured for each replication

test.steps: Create/modify a replication with an unauthorized IAM role, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Verify S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all S3 access points
countermeasure.desc: Verify S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all S3 access points (including multi-region), with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true.

test.steps:
Remove S3 Block Public Access of

  1. an access point
  2. a multi-region access point
it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Verify S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc: Verify S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all S3 buckets, with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true (e.g. using the AWS Config rule: S3_BUCKET_LEVEL_PUBLIC_ACCESS_PROHIBITED).

countermeasure.name: Verify S3 VPC endpoints blocking unauthorised IAM
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 VPC endpoint are blocking any IAM entity not belonging to an authorized AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s)

test.steps: Remove the policy statement blocking any IAM entity not belonging to an authorized AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s) from the VPC endpoint, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify that all VPC are limited to authorised S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc: Verify all VPC are limited to limit access to only authorized S3 bucket(s)

test.steps: Remove the control limiting access to only authorized S3 bucket(s), it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify that no bucket is available publicly for write or read
countermeasure.desc: Verify no bucket is available publicly for write or read (e.g. using the AWS Config rules: S3_BUCKET_PUBLIC_READ_PROHIBITED and S3_BUCKET_PUBLIC_WRITE_PROHIBITED)

test.steps: Create a public S3 bucket, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify the control blocking bucket ACL changes other than for server access logging
countermeasure.desc: Verify the control blocking bucket ACL changes other than for server access logging (e.g. an SCP, a bucket policy and VPC endpoint policy) is properly implemented

test.steps: Remove the control blocking bucket ACL changes other than for server access logging, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify the control blocking change
countermeasure.desc: Verify the control blocking change ObjectACL to public (e.g. an SCP and VPC endpoint policy) is properly implemented

test.steps: Remove the control blocking changes of ObjectACL to public, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify the control blocking the action
countermeasure.desc: Verify the control blocking the action "s3:DeleteBucket" (e.g. an SCP on your AWS Organizations root node) is properly implemented

test.steps: Remove the control blocking the action "s3:DeleteBucket" (e.g. an SCP on your root node), it should be detected.

threat.name: Bucket takeover to gather data
threat.desc:
Bucket names are globally unique. An attacker can recreate the same bucket name of a deleted bucket you used to own to collect any new data being uploaded by a non-updated party, do a DNS takeover (using a non-deleted CNAME / CloudFront origin to the bucket) or to use remaining permissions to exfiltrate data.

IAM Access

{

"OPTIONAL": "s3:DeleteBucket"

}

threat.name: Destroy or modify primary data
threat.desc:
S3 provides high durability by design (11 9s), however data can still be deleted by the customer. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can use its access to destroy (or modify) primary data located on S3, affecting the ability for the business to operate (for example, Code Spaces).

IAM Access

{

"AND": ["s3:DeleteObject", {

"OPTIONAL": "S3:DeleteObjectVersion" }, {

"OPTIONAL": "s3:BypassGovernanceMode" }]

}

threat.name: Files encrypted for ransomware
threat.desc:
S3 provides several types of encryption where the key is not operated by AWS (e.g. SSE-KMS with Bring Your Own Key). An attacker can encrypt all the data stored in S3 to ransom the data owner to get the decryption key (blog). Alternatively, an attacker can change the default encryption key, for a similar effect on any new data uploaded.

IAM Access

{

"AND": ["s3:GetObject", "s3:PutObject"]

}

threat.name: Increase bill by creating incomplete uploads
threat.desc:
By default, when a multiple upload is initiated but not completed, S3 will keep it (ref). An attacker can upload a large amount of data without completing it, while being hard to detect.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutObject"

}

threat.name: Increase bill by restoring large amount of data
threat.desc:
Restore cost can be amplified by the size and the type (i.e. expedited). An attacker can restore lots of data to generate costs.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:RestoreObject"

}

threat.name: Move prod data in non-prod environment
threat.desc:
Multiple types of environments are usually operated in AWS. An attacker can move the data from a secure location (e.g. production) to a less secure location (e.g. dev).

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:GetObject"

}

threat.name: Object made public or accessible in a private bucket you own by changing object ACL
threat.desc:
Bucket authority only prevails on object ACL when the object access is explicitly denied by the bucket authority (ref). An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change the object ACL to make it public or accessible for themselves (to exfiltrate or modify).

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutObjectAcl"

}

reference.name: Reference - How Amazon S3 authorises a request for an object operation

threat.name: Use bucket to upload a malware or modify an object to include a malware
threat.desc: S3 buckets are commonly used to distribute software. An attacker can upload malware in a bucket to better position it for later use, or directly change an object to include a malware (example).

threat.name: DoS by blocking traffic using bucket ACL
threat.desc:
Bucket ACL can allow access (e.g. for server access logging). An attacker can remove an existing permission to deny legitimate access to the bucket.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutBucketAcl"

}

threat.name: Grant unauthorised access to a private bucket by changing bucket ACL
threat.desc:
Bucket ACL can be used to give access to the bucket information, list the objects, and overwrite/delete objects. An attacker can change the bucket ACL to destroy or modify data, or exfiltrate data via the object name (1KB).

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutBucketAcl"

}

threat.name: Evade detection by disabling S3 access logs
threat.desc: S3 access logs can be used by SIEM to detect abnormal behaviours. An attacker can disable S3 access log on a bucket to evade detection.

threat.name: Grant unauthorised access to a private bucket by changing bucket policy
threat.desc:
Bucket policy can enable access to objects owned by the bucket. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change the bucket policy and make the content accessible.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutBucketPolicy"

}

threat.name: Reduce bucket security by deleting the bucket policy
threat.desc: Bucket policy can deny access to objects, as it supersedes the object authority. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can delete the bucket policy and make the content less secure.

threat.name: Use CloudFront to access private bucket
threat.desc:
CloudFront distributions can use S3 as their origin. An attacker can connect a CloudFront distribution to a private S3 bucket to get access to it.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutBucketPolicy"

}

threat.name: Exfiltrate data by using tags
threat.desc:
Objects and buckets can have tags. An attacker can use those features to exfiltrate data.

IAM Access

{

"AND": [{

"OR": ["GetObjectTagging", "s3:GetObjectVersionTagging"] }, {

"OR": ["s3:PutObjectTagging", "s3:PutObjectVersionTagging"] }]

}

threat.name: Affect data protection by removing versioning
threat.desc:
Versioning can be used as a first level of integrity protection. An attacker can suspend versioning to affect data protection of a bucket.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutBucketVersioning"

}

threat.name: Clickjacking on S3 website
threat.desc: S3 does not enforce certain security headers by default. An attacker can use an iFrame on your website to trick users to interact with their own scripts.

threat.name: Embed client-side script malware in bucket website
threat.desc:
S3 website enables users to be served client-side scripts (e.g. JavaScript). An attacker can upload a client-side script with a malware (e.g. cryptomining) on the visitor.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutObject"

}

threat.name: Intercept data in transit on the website endpoint
threat.desc: S3 website endpoint is serving HTTP only. An attacker can intercept HTTP traffic to steal data.

threat.name: Hotlinking content from S3 bucket
threat.desc: S3 charges for hosting and data transfer out. An attacker can hotlink your content hosted on S3 on another page to avoid paying the S3 charges (ref).

threat.name: Exfiltrate data via inventory
threat.desc:
Inventory sends the object names (i.e. keys) to any configured S3 bucket. An attacker can use the name of objects (1KB) to exfiltrate data.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutBucketInventory"

}

threat.name: Exfiltrate data via event notification
threat.desc: Event notification sends the key to any configured SQS, SNS or Lambda (cross- account), or EventBridge (same account). An attacker can use the name of objects (1KB) to exfiltrate data.

threat.name: Affect data protection by removing replication
threat.desc:
Replication can be used as a level of integrity protection and backup. An attacker can remove replication to affect the data protection.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutReplicationConfiguration"

}

threat.name: Unauthorised access to data via bucket replication
threat.desc: Replication allows you to replicate objects, their metadata and change ownership. The configuration focuses on new objects only (old objects replication requires a ticket to AWS Support). An attacker can configure replication on a bucket to replicate objects (or its metadata or tagging) in a bucket they control to exfiltrate data.

threat.name: Unauthorised object restore into an unauthorised bucket
threat.desc:
Objects can be stored in S3 Glacier. An attacker can restore an object to an unauthorised S3 bucket to collect or exfiltrate data.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:RestoreObject"

}

weakness.name: Restrict access point access to VPC when in use
Unauthorised AWS accounts Accessing KMS Keys

countermeasure.name: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key (e.g. using an SCP, bucket policy and VPC endpoint deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not a KMS key from an authorized AWS accounts)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with a KMS key from unauthorized AWS account, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 Block Public Access on all S3 access points
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C54]
Enable S3 Block Public Access on all S3 access points (including multi-region), with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true.

test.steps:
1. Create a public bucket and try to access via access point one of its objects without proper authentication (ref)

  2. change the ACL of an existing object to public and try to access via access point one of its objects

they should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized access between VPC, S3 access point and S3.
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized access between VPC, S3 access point and S3.

test.steps: Request the list of authorized access between VPC and S3 access point

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account

test.steps: Request the list of authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Monitor that only authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C31]
Monitor that only authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account (using CloudTrail S3 data events in response.x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms- key-id)

test.steps: Make a call to an unauthorized bucket, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all S3 access points
countermeasure.desc: Verify S3 Block Public Access is enabled on all S3 access points (including multi-region), with BlockPublicAcls, IgnorePublicAcls, BlockPublicPolicy, and RestrictPublicBuckets set to true.

test.steps:
Remove S3 Block Public Access of

  1. an access point
  2. a multi-region access point
it should be detected

threat.name: Grant unauthorised access to a bucket by changing/deleting access point policy
threat.desc:
Access point policy can enable access to objects owned by the bucket. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change the access point policy and make the content accessible.

IAM Access

{

"OR": ["s3:PutAccessPointPolicy", "s3:DeleteAccessPointPolicy"]

}

threat.name: Unauthorised collection of data by swapping access point
threat.desc:
Access points can be deleted and recreated with the same name, and therefore the same ARN. An attacker can delete an access point and recreate the same, on a bucket (in the same account) it controls to collect/modify data; or making it accessible from the Internet.

IAM Access

{

"AND": ["s3:CreateAccessPoint", "s3:DeleteAccessPoint"]

}

weakness.name: Block all requests not using HTTP authorization header, if not explicitly authorized
Limit access from only authorized VPCs
S3 endpoints accessible through corporate perimeter
Unauthorised TLS version(s) from IAM entities you control access
Unencrypted access via HTTP not tracked or monitored
weakness.desc: Monitor and investigate that all requests made with HTTP (e.g via CloudTrail S3 data events with the lack of additionalEventData.CipherSuite)

weakness.name: Unencrypted requests to S3 bucket you control are allowed

countermeasure.name: Block all requests not using HTTP authorization header
countermeasure.desc: Block all requests not using HTTP authorization header, i.e. presign via query strings or POST (ref) (e.g. using an SCP and S3 policy on all buckets with deny on "StringNotEquals":{"s3:authType": "REST-HEADER"}). Note it blocks uploads via the console, as well.

test.steps: Make a request with a non-HTTP authorization header, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Block all unencrypted requests and unauthorised TLS version(s) from IAM entities you control
countermeasure.desc:
[S3.C1, depends on S3.C119, assured by S3.C2]


Block all unencrypted requests and unauthorised TLS version(s) from IAM entities you control

e.g.

by denying all unencrypted request with the condition "aws:SecureTransport" = False,

or by using "s3:TlsVersion" !=authorized TLS version(s), using an SCP on your AWS Organization root node

test.steps: Make an unencrypted S3 API call, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Block all unencrypted requests to S3 bucket you control
countermeasure.desc:
[S3.C6, depends on S3.C119, assured by S3.C7]


Block all unencrypted requests to S3 bucket you control (e.g. by denying all requests with the condition "aws:SecureTransport" = False, or by using "s3:TlsVersion" != authorized TLS version(s), on the S3 bucket policy)

countermeasure.name: Block S3 endpoints in your corporate perimeter security to the Internet
countermeasure.desc:
Block S3 endpoints (DNS and IP ranges) in your corporate perimeter security to the Internet (e.g. firewalls, or cloud interception proxy like Kivera) including via Internet Gateway, to force usage of VPC endpoints. It will block data-plane transfer.

Note: AWS console stays functional as it proxies non- data-plane requests (via "console.aws.amazon.com").

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events
countermeasure.desc: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events in relevant AWS accounts, Regions and buckets (e.g. production, with sensitive data, etc.). Make it available for security analysis, and protect it using CloudTrail ThreatModel

test.steps: Request the CloudTrail ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling and protecting S3 data events

countermeasure.name: Enable GuardDuty Monitoring
countermeasure.desc: Enable and monitor S3 protection in Amazon GuardDuty in all AWS accounts in all Regions, and protect it using GuardDuty ThreatModel. Ensure findings are investigated (e.g. using Amazon Detective).

test.steps: Request the GuardDuty ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling, monitoring, investigation and protecting S3 protection

countermeasure.name: For each S3 bucket, maintain a list of VPC(s), authorized to access it.
countermeasure.desc: For each S3 bucket, maintain a list of VPC(s), authorized to access it.

test.steps: For each S3 bucket, request the list of authorized VPC to access it, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to authorised VPC
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C98, assured by S3.C100]
Limit the access to only those VPC(s) (e.g. using S3 bucket statement, deny if the condition "aws:SourceVpce", or if the bucket policy size is beyond the limit, use this condition on access point)

test.steps: Make a request to the bucket outside an authorized VPC, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorised version(s) of TLS/SSL
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorised version(s) of TLS/SSL per bucket (or per account/OU/Org)

countermeasure.name: Monitor and investigate that all requests made with HTTP
countermeasure.desc: Monitor and investigate that all requests made with HTTP (e.g via CloudTrail S3 data events with the lack of additionalEventData.CipherSuite)

test.steps: Make an unencrypted AWS API call from one of your VPC with VPC endpoint, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Monitor and investigate that all requests not using HTTP authorization header
countermeasure.desc: Monitor and investigate that all requests not using HTTP authorization header (e.g via CloudTrail S3 with the additionalEventData.AuthenticationMethod different from "AuthHeader")

test.steps:
Make

  1. a presigned AWS API call
  2. a POST request
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Verify all buckets include a control to limit access to only authorized VPC(s)
countermeasure.desc: Verify all buckets include a control to limit access to only authorized VPC(s) (e.g. using the AWS Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK)

test.steps: Remove the control limiting access to only authorized VPC(s), it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 bucket policies block unencrypted traffic
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket policies block unencrypted traffic (e.g. using the AWS Config rule: S3_BUCKET_SSL_REQUESTS_ONLY) and unauthorised version(s) of TLS.

countermeasure.name: Verify control blocking unencrypted requests
countermeasure.desc: Verify the control blocking unencrypted requests and unauthorised TLS version(s) from IAM entities you control (e.g. an SCP on your AWS Organisations root node) is properly implemented

threat.name: Exfiltrate data by using of a compromised IAM access from Internet
threat.desc: IAM credentials can be compromised (directly or using pre-signed URL). An attacker can use a compromised but authorized IAM credential to download your object from an internal bucket via the public endpoint (using or not their own VPC endpoint).

threat.name: Intercept data in transit to an internal bucket
threat.desc:
S3 allows communication over HTTP.

An attacker can intercept the traffic you send on an internal bucket, in order to read or modify the data.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:any"

}

threat.name: Reduce bucket security by modify the account public access block
threat.desc:
Account public access block protect all buckets of an AWS account from leakage (e.g. object ACL set to public). An attacker can remove this protection by modifying the account public access block.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutAccountPublicAccessBlock"

}

weakness.name: Unlimited/MOnitored access via S3 VPC Endpoints

countermeasure.name: S3 VPC Endpoints covered by VPC endpoint controls
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all S3 VPC endpoints (Interface and Gateway) are covered by the VPC endpoints controls

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring all S3 VPC endpoints (Interface and Gateway) are covered by the VPC endpoints controls, and its records

threat.name: Exfiltrate data via ungoverned S3 endpoint
threat.desc:
S3 VPC endpoints can be either Interface or Gateway. An attacker can create a second endpoint to create an ungoverned exfiltration vector.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "ec2:CreateVpcEndpoint"

}

Unauthorised AWS accounts Accessing KMS Keys

countermeasure.name: Aligned with your data governance
countermeasure.desc: Aligned with your data governance, encrypt on the client side - or tokenize - appropriate data

countermeasure.name: Allow only authorised ACL
countermeasure.desc: Allow only authorized ACL on objects for bucket you don't control (e.g. using IAM and VPC endpoint policy with the ACL conditions)

test.steps: Put an object with an unauthorized ACL, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Block all traffic from Internet-configured S3 access point
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C111]
Block all traffic from Internet-configured S3 access point (e.g. on the bucket policy, using a deny statement with the condition "StringNotEquals": {"s3:AccessPointNetworkOrigin": "VPC"})

test.steps: Create an internet-facing access point and try to access a bucket, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Block object access to S3 bucket not via an AP
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C104]
Block any object-related operations access to S3 bucket not through access point (i.e. using a deny IAM policy statement with the condition "ArnNotLike" {"s3:DataAccessPointArn": "arn:aws:s3:Region:AccountId:accesspoint/*"})

test.steps: Access any S3 bucket using the S3 public endpoint, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key (e.g. using an SCP, bucket policy and VPC endpoint deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not a KMS key from an authorized AWS accounts)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with a KMS key from unauthorized AWS account, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Block S3 endpoints in your corporate perimeter security to the Internet

Block S3 endpoints (DNS and IP ranges) in your corporate perimeter security to the Internet (e.g. firewalls, or cloud interception proxy like Kivera) including via Internet Gateway, to force usage of VPC endpoints. It will block data-plane transfer.

Note: AWS console stays functional as it proxies non- data-plane requests (via "console.aws.amazon.com").

countermeasure.name: Block the creation of non-VPC S3 access point
countermeasure.desc: Block the creation "s3:CreateAccessPoint" of non-VPC S3 access point (e.g. using the condition "StringNotEquals": {"s3:AccessPointNetworkOrigin": "VPC"})

test.steps: Do a request to create an internet-based access point, it should be denied.

[assured by S3.C110]
In S3 bucket policy, deny all IAM principals not using an authorized S3 access point(s) using the condition "s3:DataAccessPointAccount" or preferably "s3:DataAccessPointArn"

Limit access via the S3 access point by using in VPC endpoint and/or bucket policy the condition "s3:DataAccessPointAccount" or preferably "s3:DataAccessPointArn" in an allow statement to reduce the length of allowlist bucket name in VPC endpoint/bucket policy.

countermeasure.desc: Monitor that only authorised external buckets are used (e.g. via CloudTrail S3 data events in resources[].accountId and resources[].ARN). Both account ID and bucket name must be verified.

countermeasure.desc: Track all buckets you don't control hosting your objects, define their authorised data classification, identify their respective owners (and AWS account ID), their ObjectACL requirements (including S3 Object Ownership), and get assured for the protection (e.g. through contractual agreement, verified by assurance programs, or using this ThreatModel).

threat.name: Exfiltrate data by using the public endpoint to upload data in an attacker bucket, using external credentials
threat.desc: AWS authenticates per AWS account. An attacker can bring its own credentials to exfiltrate data to external S3 buckets through the S3 public endpoint. It can be a non-authenticated user as well.

usecase.name: S3 allows IAM Entities to upload data in a bucket in other AWS Accounts

threat.name: Exfiltrate data to an attacker bucket via public endpoint
threat.desc:
S3 allows IAM entities to upload data in a bucket in other AWS accounts, if they have the IAM permissions. An attacker can use one of your IAM entities to upload data to one of their buckets. If the attacker does not control object ACL, it can use the name of objects (1KB).

IAM Access

{

"AND": ["s3:PutObject", {

"OPTIONAL": "s3:PutObjectAcl" }]

}

weakness.name: Control IAM roles used for Batch

threat.name: Exfiltrate, modify or delete objects using Batch
threat.desc:
S3 Batch Operations require an IAM role (with proper trust policy), then can run operations including copy, or replace/delete object tags. An attacker can use Batch copy or modify objects to exfiltrate or change the access management of an object (if relying on tag).

IAM Access

{

"AND": ["s3:CreateJob", "iam:PassRole"]

}

Note it does not block someone to enable ACL afterwards via PutPutBucketOwnershipControls.
