threat.name: Gain unauthorised access to buckets trusting all Multi-Region Access Points
threat.desc:
Buckets used by Multi-Region Access Points can be configured to delegate their access to any MRAP using the condition "s3:DataAccessPointAccount". An attacker can create a MRAP, add any misconfigured bucket and gain access to it.

IAM Access

{

"AND": ["s3:CreateMultiRegionAccessPoint", "s3:PutMultiRegionAccessPointPolicy"]

}

threat.name: Grant unauthorised access to buckets by changing the Multi-Region Access Point policy
threat.desc:
Multi-Region Access Point policy can enable access to objects owned by the bucket. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change the Multi-Region Access Point policy and make the content accessible.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutMultiRegionAccessPointPolicy"

}

weakness.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats
Protect and/or claim your domains and trademarks/copyrights
Restrict access point access to VPC when in use
S3 endpoints accessible through corporate perimeter
Unauthorised AWS accounts Accessing KMS Keys
Unauthorised TLS version(s) from IAM entities you control access
Unauthorised TLS version(s) from VPC endpoints you control provide access
Unencrypted access via HTTP not tracked or monitored
weakness.desc: Monitor and investigate that all requests made with HTTP (e.g via CloudTrail S3 data events with the lack of additionalEventData.CipherSuite)

weakness.name: Unlimited/MOnitored access via S3 VPC Endpoints

countermeasure.name: Aligned with your data governance
countermeasure.desc: Aligned with your data governance, encrypt on the client side - or tokenize - appropriate data

test.steps: Request the governance and mechanism(s) used to protect data (e.g. encrypt or tokenize critical data on the client side

countermeasure.name: A statement exists on all your VPC endpoint policy denying all requests
countermeasure.desc: Verify a statement exists on all your VPC endpoint policy denying all requests with the condition "aws:SecureTransport" = False

test.steps: Create/remove the statement on a VPC endpoint policy denying 1) all unencrypted requests or 2) unauthorized TLS version(s), it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Block all unencrypted requests and unauthorised TLS version(s) from IAM entities you control
countermeasure.desc:
[S3.C1, depends on S3.C119, assured by S3.C2]


Block all unencrypted requests and unauthorised TLS version(s) from IAM entities you control

e.g.

by denying all unencrypted request with the condition "aws:SecureTransport" = False,

or by using "s3:TlsVersion" !=authorized TLS version(s), using an SCP on your AWS Organization root node

test.steps: Make an unencrypted S3 API call, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Block all unencrypted requests and unauthorised TLS version(s) from VPC endpoints you control
countermeasure.desc:
[S3.C3, depends on S3.C119, assured by S3.C5]


Block all unencrypted requests and unauthorised TLS version(s) from VPC endpoints you control (e.g. by denying all requests with the condition "aws:SecureTransport" = False, or by using "s3:TlsVersion" != authorized TLS version(s), on the VPC endpoint policy)

test.steps: Make an unencrypted AWS API call from one of your VPC with VPC endpoint, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key (e.g. using an SCP, bucket policy and VPC endpoint deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not a KMS key from an authorized AWS accounts)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with a KMS key from unauthorized AWS account, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Block S3 endpoints in your corporate perimeter security to the Internet
countermeasure.desc:
Block S3 endpoints (DNS and IP ranges) in your corporate perimeter security to the Internet (e.g. firewalls, or cloud interception proxy like Kivera) including via Internet Gateway, to force usage of VPC endpoints. It will block data-plane transfer.

Note: AWS console stays functional as it proxies non- data-plane requests (via "console.aws.amazon.com").

countermeasure.name: block Unauthorised IAM entity
countermeasure.desc: Block any IAM entity not belonging to an authorized AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s) to call S3 from your VPCs by adding a deny statement on S3 VPC endpoint policy of each VPC, with the condition using "aws:PrincipalOrgPaths" (ref) including the full Org ID, as those are globally unique.

test.steps: For each VPC, do an API call with an IAM entity which is not part of its authorized AWS Organizations path(s), it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events
countermeasure.desc: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events in relevant AWS accounts, Regions and buckets (e.g. production, with sensitive data, etc.). Make it available for security analysis, and protect it using CloudTrail ThreatModel

test.steps: Request the CloudTrail ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling and protecting S3 data events

countermeasure.name: Enable GuardDuty Monitoring
countermeasure.desc: Enable and monitor S3 protection in Amazon GuardDuty in all AWS accounts in all Regions, and protect it using GuardDuty ThreatModel. Ensure findings are investigated (e.g. using Amazon Detective).

test.steps: Request the GuardDuty ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling, monitoring, investigation and protecting S3 protection

countermeasure.name: Enable Macie
countermeasure.desc: Enable S3 policy findings in Amazon Macie in all AWS accounts in all Regions, and protect it using Macie ThreatModel

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC DNS query logging
countermeasure.desc: Enable VPC DNS query logging in all VPC

test.steps: Request the mechanism to enable VPC DNS query logging in all VPC

countermeasure.name: Ensure all S3 buckets interacted with are in the correct AWS account
countermeasure.desc: Ensure all S3 buckets interacted with are in the correct AWS account (e.g. using the condition in all compatible S3 requests: x-amz-expected-bucket-owner and x-amz-source-expected- bucket-owner)

countermeasure.name: Limit access to only authorised S3 bucket
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to only authorized S3 bucket(s) or their AWS account(s) from each VPC (e.g. using the condition key "s3:ResourceAccount" on the VPC endpoint policy, alternatively use specific resource-level statement for each bucket, or if the VPC endpoint policy size is beyond the limit and more granular control on VPC is required, use access points)

test.steps: Make a request to an unauthorized bucket from one of your VPC, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Limit access via the S3 access point
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C104, assured by S3.C109]
Limit access via the S3 access point by using in VPC endpoint and/or bucket policy the condition "s3:DataAccessPointAccount" or preferably "s3:DataAccessPointArn" in an allow statement to reduce the length of allowlist bucket name in VPC endpoint/bucket policy.

test.steps: Do a request on an unauthorized access point or bucket, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorised version(s) of TLS/SSL
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorised version(s) of TLS/SSL per bucket (or per account/OU/Org)

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized access between VPC, S3 access point and S3.
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized access between VPC, S3 access point and S3.

test.steps: Request the list of authorized access between VPC and S3 access point

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account

test.steps: Request the list of authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain comprehensive list of those accessing S3
countermeasure.desc: For each VPC, maintain a list of AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s), where IAM entities are authorized to access S3

test.steps: For each VPC, request the list of AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s), where IAM entities are authorized to access S3, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain list of authorised S3 and S3 Access points
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized S3 and S3 access point (and their respective AWS accounts) to be access for each VPC

test.steps: Request the list of authorized S3 and S3 access point to be access for each VPC, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Monitor and investigate that all requests made with HTTP
countermeasure.desc: Monitor and investigate that all requests made with HTTP (e.g via CloudTrail S3 data events with the lack of additionalEventData.CipherSuite)

test.steps: Make an unencrypted AWS API call from one of your VPC with VPC endpoint, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Monitor external buckets to ensure only those authorised are used
countermeasure.desc: Monitor that only authorised external buckets are used (e.g. via CloudTrail S3 data events in resources[].accountId and resources[].ARN). Both account ID and bucket name must be verified.

test.steps: Make a call to an unauthorized bucket, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Monitor that only authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C31]
Monitor that only authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account (using CloudTrail S3 data events in response.x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms- key-id)

test.steps: Make a call to an unauthorized bucket, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Monitor VPC DNS query log
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C21,S3.C22]

Monitor VPC DNS query logs that only authorised S3 bucket and S3 access points are being queried in each VPC (e.g. using VPC DNS query logging), and protect it using Route53 ThreatModel

test.steps: Make a DNS query to an unauthorized 1) S3 bucket and 2) S3 access points, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Protect and/or claim your domains and trademarks/copyrights
countermeasure.desc: Protect and/or claim your domains and trademarks/copyrights (by creating your trademark buckets, and using the copyright infringement process from AWS)

test.steps: Request the process by protecting and/or claiming your domains and trademarks/copyright

countermeasure.name: Request access via S3 access point
countermeasure.desc: Request access via S3 access point on bucket you don't own, if compatible with your interaction with the bucket (e.g. not through not-compatible AWS service)

test.steps: Request the documented reason access point was not implemented in the use case

countermeasure.name: Scan all data uploaded to external buckets
countermeasure.desc: Scan all data before uploading to an external bucket to ensure the classification of the data is aligned with the bucket classification (e.g. using Macie).

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism ensuring all data are scanned for proper data classification before upload to an external bucket are configured
  2. its records of execution for all object upload flows
  3. plan to move any older object upload flows

countermeasure.name: Secure with VPC Threat Model
countermeasure.desc: For each VPC with an IAM entity allowed to use S3, secure them with the VPC ThreatModel (e.g. modification of VPC endpoints, VPC endpoint policy, routing table, Security Groups)

countermeasure.name: Track all buckets you do not control that host your objects
countermeasure.desc: Track all buckets you don't control hosting your objects, define their authorised data classification, identify their respective owners (and AWS account ID), their ObjectACL requirements (including S3 Object Ownership), and get assured for the protection (e.g. through contractual agreement, verified by assurance programs, or using this ThreatModel).

test.steps: Request the list of all authorized external buckets authorized to host your objects, their respective owners (and AWS account ID), their ObjectACL requirements (including S3 Object Ownership), their data classification and the mechanism used to ensure the security of those buckets

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Use unguessable naming convention
countermeasure.desc: Use unguessable naming convention for the email addresses of your AWS accounts (e.g. add a + sign and a random string to redirect the email in the same mailbox)

test.steps: Review naming convention for root account email and their implementation

countermeasure.name: Use unguessable naming convention for your IAM users and IAM roles
countermeasure.desc: Use unguessable naming convention for your IAM users and IAM roles (e.g. add a random string)

test.steps: Review naming convention for IAM users/role and their implementation

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify control blocking unencrypted requests
countermeasure.desc: Verify the control blocking unencrypted requests and unauthorised TLS version(s) from IAM entities you control (e.g. an SCP on your AWS Organisations root node) is properly implemented

countermeasure.name: Verify only access points are used in the resource-level statement in VPC endpoints
countermeasure.desc: Verify only access points are used in the resource-level statement in VPC endpoints

test.steps: Create a VPC endpoint giving access to an S3 bucket, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify S3 VPC endpoints blocking unauthorised IAM
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 VPC endpoint are blocking any IAM entity not belonging to an authorized AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s)

test.steps: Remove the policy statement blocking any IAM entity not belonging to an authorized AWS Organizations, OU and/or AWS account(s) from the VPC endpoint, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify that all VPC are limited to authorised S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc: Verify all VPC are limited to limit access to only authorized S3 bucket(s)

test.steps: Remove the control limiting access to only authorized S3 bucket(s), it should be detected.

threat.name: Exfiltrate data by using tags
threat.desc:
Objects and buckets can have tags. An attacker can use those features to exfiltrate data.

IAM Access

{

"AND": [{

"OR": ["GetObjectTagging", "s3:GetObjectVersionTagging"] }, {

"OR": ["s3:PutObjectTagging", "s3:PutObjectVersionTagging"] }]

}

threat.name: Affect data protection by removing versioning
threat.desc:
Versioning can be used as a first level of integrity protection. An attacker can suspend versioning to affect data protection of a bucket.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutBucketVersioning"

}

threat.name: Phishing using trademarks
threat.desc: S3 provides URLs to buckets using the bucket name (i.e. "mybucket.s3.amazonaws.com"). An attacker can create a bucket with the name of your trademark to phish users.

threat.name: Recon of AWS root account emails using email ACL grantee feature
threat.desc: S3 allows you to add root account emails in ACL (ref), and as well resolve the given canonical ID into an AWS account ID (via a bucket policy, which automatically resolves a canonical ID into an ARN). An attacker can do trial-and- error to discover existing AWS root account emails and related AWS account ID (even if you do not use the region where the feature is available); and use this information to launch another attack (e.g. phishing).

threat.name: Recon on information about a bucket
threat.desc: Error messages can give some information about specific buckets. An attacker who knows the bucket name can find its AWS account and AWS Region. To find the AWS Region, use "aws s3 presign bucket-name/whatever" the error message will give you the region if not in the right region. To find the account, look at the call in CloudTrail (with S3 data enabled) under the resource section.

threat.name: Recon on valid AWS account or IAM principals
threat.desc: AWS provides error messages in S3 bucket policy that can be used for basic recon. An attacker can discover whether an AWS account with a specific AWS account ID or AWS IAM principals exists, by modifying the S3 policy to grant some rights to the said AWS account/IAM principal.

threat.name: Intercept data in transit to an external bucket
threat.desc:
S3 allows communication over HTTP. An attacker can intercept the traffic you send on an external bucket, in order to read or modify the data.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:any"

}

threat.name: Exfiltrate data by uploading it to an attacker bucket using a non-authenticated user or an unauthorised external IAM entity via one of your S3 VPC endpoints
threat.desc: VPC endpoints for S3 allow any entity to connect from a VPC to any S3 bucket without Internet Gateway. An attacker can exfiltrate data to an external S3 bucket via one of your VPC endpoints, using a non-authenticated user or its own external IAM entity. Note that some external IAM entities might be authorised, if provided by one of your business partners.

threat.name: Exfiltrate your data hosted on an external bucket, by using of a compromised IAM access from Internet
threat.desc:
IAM credentials can be compromised. An attacker can use a compromised but authorised credential to download your object from an external bucket via the public endpoint (using or not their own VPC endpoint). 


IAM Access

{


"UNIQUE": "s3:GetObject"

}

threat.name: Unauthorised upload of a private object in an accessible bucket (e.g. public) you do not own
threat.desc:
S3 buckets can be public for a legitimate reason. An attacker (or someone by negligence) can upload sensitive data in an accessible bucket (e.g. public) you do not own to make it accessible to exfiltrate it.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutObject"

}

threat.name: Upload in an authorised external bucket, but in an incorrect AWS account
threat.desc:
Bucket names are globally unique. An attacker can take over a legitimate external bucket, and deceive you into sending it to their bucket.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutObject"

}

component.name: Object (Internal)
component.desc: Your Object + Version(s) or Ownership-given Object

weakness.name: Identify and ensure the protection all internal buckets hosting your objects
Limit access from only authorized VPCs
Unauthorised AWS accounts Accessing KMS Keys
Use S3 Object Lock to protect data integrity

countermeasure.name: Backup primary data in a secure location under a different security authority
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C58]

Backup primary data in a secure location under a different security authority (e.g. in an AWS data bunker account via replication)

test.steps: Request the mechanism used to backup primary data in a location which have different security authority, its records of execution, and records of restoration testing

countermeasure.name: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key (e.g. using an SCP, bucket policy and VPC endpoint deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not a KMS key from an authorized AWS accounts)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with a KMS key from unauthorized AWS account, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: For each S3 bucket, maintain a list of VPC(s), authorized to access it.
countermeasure.desc: For each S3 bucket, maintain a list of VPC(s), authorized to access it.

test.steps: For each S3 bucket, request the list of authorized VPC to access it, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Implement the authorized default S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C58, assured by S3.C75]
Implement the authorized default S3 Object Lock on each bucket (note: Amazon S3 evaluates and applies bucket policies before applying bucket default S3 Object Lock settings)

test.steps: Upload an object without appropriate S3 Object Lock, it should have the S3 Object Lock automatically.

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to authorised VPC
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C98, assured by S3.C100]
Limit the access to only those VPC(s) (e.g. using S3 bucket statement, deny if the condition "aws:SourceVpce", or if the bucket policy size is beyond the limit, use this condition on access point)

test.steps: Make a request to the bucket outside an authorized VPC, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account

test.steps: Request the list of authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Monitor that only authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C31]
Monitor that only authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account (using CloudTrail S3 data events in response.x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms- key-id)

test.steps: Make a call to an unauthorized bucket, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Track all buckets you control and define data classification
countermeasure.desc: Track all buckets you control, define their authorized data classification, identify whether the hosted data is primary (i.e. source of truth, for example logs, backups, forensic data, raw data, etc.) or an input/output of a process (e.g. file-processing, software package, etc.), their WORM requirements (e.g. SEC 17a-4, CTCC, etc.), if they are production/non-production (preferably done at account-level), their storage class. You may use tags, Infra-as-code, AWS Glue Data Catalog or external management tool like FINRA herd)

test.steps: Request the list of all buckets you control, define their authorized data classification, identify whether the data is primary and the mechanism and records to ensure the accuracy of those metadata

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Verify all buckets have the correct default S3 Object Lock configuration
countermeasure.desc: Verify all buckets have the correct default S3 Object Lock configuration

test.steps:
Create a bucket either

  1. without S3 Object Lock
  2. with an incorrect default S3 Object Lock
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all buckets include a control to limit access to only authorized VPC(s)
countermeasure.desc: Verify all buckets include a control to limit access to only authorized VPC(s) (e.g. using the AWS Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK)

test.steps: Remove the control limiting access to only authorized VPC(s), it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: When using etaf properly account for definitions
countermeasure.desc: if etag is used, make sure properly account for its different definitions (ref)

test.steps: Request the process ensuring etag different definitions are properly accounted for

threat.name: Abuse MD5 etag
threat.desc: Etags includes the MD5 of the file but not consistently and can be used by developers to verify the integrity of a file. An attacker can affect an upload function to change the etag of a file, in order to disrupt a workflow downstream.

threat.name: Delete objects by using lifecycle
threat.desc:
Lifecycle allows you to delete objects after its configured expiry. An attacker can use a lifecycle configuration to destroy data.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutLifecycleConfiguration"

}

threat.name: Gain access by modifying or deleting important object tags
threat.desc:
Tags can be used for various reasons, including security classification or access management (via ABAC). An attacker can change the tagging of an object to another value enabling them to execute another attack.

IAM Access

{

"OR": ["s3:PutObjectTagging", "s3:DeleteObjectTagging"]

}

weakness.name: Threats on all AWS Services accessing S3 not quantified
weakness.desc: Many AWS Services access and utilise S3, you need to ensure that you understand the risk assocaited with these services and the buckets that they utilise

weakness.name: Unauthorised AWS accounts Accessing KMS Keys

countermeasure.name: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Block requests with unauthorised AWS account providing the KMS key (e.g. using an SCP, bucket policy and VPC endpoint deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not a KMS key from an authorized AWS accounts)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with a KMS key from unauthorized AWS account, it should be denied

countermeasure.desc: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events in relevant AWS accounts, Regions and buckets (e.g. production, with sensitive data, etc.). Make it available for security analysis, and protect it using CloudTrail ThreatModel

countermeasure.desc: Enforce usage in VPC only, whenever possible.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account

test.steps: Request the list of authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys for S3 for each AWS account, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Monitor external buckets to ensure only those authorised are used
countermeasure.desc: Monitor that only authorised external buckets are used (e.g. via CloudTrail S3 data events in resources[].accountId and resources[].ARN). Both account ID and bucket name must be verified.

test.steps: Make a call to an unauthorized bucket, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Monitor that only authorised AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C31]
Monitor that only authorized AWS accounts to provide KMS keys are used for each AWS account (using CloudTrail S3 data events in response.x-amz-server-side-encryption-aws-kms- key-id)

test.steps: Make a call to an unauthorized bucket, it should be detected

countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  2. in an access point policy

usecase.name: Services with IAM roles will give ownership to the target AWS account

threat.name: Exfiltrate data stored on S3 via AWS services
threat.desc:
Number of AWS services are using S3 for storage, including storing in cross- account S3 buckets. Services with IAM roles (e.g. SageMaker) will give ownership to the target AWS account, hence removing the ownership protection. An attacker can use those services to exfiltrate data.


IAM Access

{

"OPTIONAL": "s3:PutObjectAcl"

}

component.name: Object Lambda Access Point (associated with one AP at a time

weakness.name: Enforce only authorized Object Lambda access point and associated access

countermeasure.name: Create only Authorised Lambda functions
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C125, assured by S3.C127]
Ensure only authorized Lambda function for each Object Lambda access point, its associated access point, its associated GET request(s), and payload are created

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring only authorized Lambda function for each Object Lambda access point, its associated access point, its associated GET request(s), and payload, and the evidence of its execution

countermeasure.name: Ensure CloudWatch is enabled for all Object Lambda access points
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C133]
Ensure CloudWatch is enabled for all Object Lambda access points

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring CloudWatch is enabled for all Object Lambda access points, and its records of execution

countermeasure.name: Ensure Lambda functions configured on Object Lambda access point are secured using Lambda ThreatModel
countermeasure.desc: Ensure Lambda functions configured on Object Lambda access point are secured using Lambda ThreatModel

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring Lambda ThreatModel and its application for Lambda functions associated to Object Lambda access point, and its records of execution

countermeasure.name: Ensure only authorized cross-account IAM entities are allowed in the Object Lambda access point policy
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C129, assured by S3.C131]
Ensure only authorized cross-account IAM entities are allowed in the Object Lambda access point policy

test.steps: Request the mechanism ensuring only cross-account IAM entities are allowed in the Object Lambda access point policy, and the evidence of its execution

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized Lambda function for each Object Lambda access point
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized Lambda function for each Object Lambda access point, its associated access point, its associated GET request(s), and payload

test.steps: Request the list of authorized Lambda function for each Object Lambda access point, its associated access point, its associated GET request(s), and payload, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of cross-account access on each Object Lambda access point
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of cross-account access on each Object Lambda access point

test.steps: Request the list of authorized cross-account access for each Object Lambda access point, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify CloudWatch is enabled for all Object Lambda access points
countermeasure.desc: Verify CloudWatch is enabled for all Object Lambda access points

test.steps: Create an Object Lambda access point without CloudWatch enabled, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify existance of authorized Lambda function only on defined objects
countermeasure.desc: Verify only the authorized Lambda function are configured on each Object Lambda access point, its associated access point, its associated GET request(s), and payload

test.steps:
Attach

  1. an unauthorized Lambda function on an Object Lambda access point
  2. an unauthorized Object Lambda access point to an access point
  3. an authorized Lambda function with an unauthorized GET request on an Object Lambda access point,
  4. an authorized Lambda function with an unauthorized payload
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify only the authorized cross-account IAM entities are allowed in the Object Lambda access point policy
countermeasure.desc: Verify only the authorized cross-account IAM entities are allowed in the Object Lambda access point policy

test.steps: Add an unauthorized cross-account IAM entity on an Object Lambda access point policy, it should be detected.

threat.name: Hijack connection with an Object Lambda
threat.desc:
Object Lambda are invoked between the access point and the object. An attacker can configure a Lambda to modify, snoop or exfiltrate data. 

IAM Access
{
"OR": ["s3:CreateAccessPointForObjectLambda", "s3:PutAccessPointConfigurationForObjectLambda"]
}

component.name: Object (External)
component.desc: Your Object + Version(s) or Ownership-given Object

weakness.name: Changes to make an object public via object ACL

countermeasure.name: Allow only authorised ACL
countermeasure.desc: Allow only authorized ACL on objects for bucket you don't control (e.g. using IAM and VPC endpoint policy with the ACL conditions)

test.steps: Put an object with an unauthorized ACL, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Block the PubObject with any ACL operation
countermeasure.desc:
For all external bucket with bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirement but without S3 Object Ownership handover, block the PutObject with any ACL (e.g. using IAM or SCP and a deny on the condition "StringLike": {"s3:x-amz-acl": "*"}).

It should be called via PutObjectAcl.

test.steps: Make a request to an external bucket with bucket-owner- full-control ACL requirement but without S3 Object Ownership handover requirement, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Deny requests to change object ACL to public
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C36]
Deny requests to change object ACL to public (e.g. using an SCP, S3 bucket policy and VPC endpoint policy blocking PutObjectAcl for "s3:x-amz-grant-read", "s3:x-amz-grant- read-acp", "s3:x-amz-grant-write-acp", "s3:x-amz-grant-full- control" on the following predefined groups "http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/AllUsers" and "http://acs.amazonaws.com/groups/global/AuthenticatedUsers")

test.steps: Make a call to create a public ObjectACL, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events
countermeasure.desc: Enable CloudTrail S3 data events in relevant AWS accounts, Regions and buckets (e.g. production, with sensitive data, etc.). Make it available for security analysis, and protect it using CloudTrail ThreatModel

test.steps: Request the CloudTrail ThreatModel and the evidence of its application for enabling and protecting S3 data events

countermeasure.name: Ensure bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C154]
Ensure bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket

test.steps:
Request

  1. the mechanism ensuring bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket
  2. its records of execution for all new buckets
  3. plan to move any older buckets

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Monitor and investigate anonymous requests to objects
countermeasure.desc: Monitor and investigate anonymous requests to objects (e.g. using CloudTrail S3 data events with userIdentity.accountId=ANONYMOUS_PRINCIPAL)

test.steps: Make an anonymous call, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Monitor ObjectACL change
countermeasure.desc: Monitor ObjectACL changed (or tentatively changed) to public using CloudTrail S3 data events

test.steps: Make a call to create a public ObjectACL, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Monitor PutObject does not include ACL
countermeasure.desc: For all external bucket with bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirement but without S3 Object Ownership handover, monitor that the PutObject do not include the ACL operation

test.steps: Make a request to an external bucket with bucket-owner- full-control ACL requirement but without S3 Object Ownership handover requirement, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Object Transmission Do not use built in Object ACL operation
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C11]
When transmitting an object to an external bucket with bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirement but without S3 Object Ownership handover, use 2 separate APIs (PutObject and PutObjectAcl), instead of the built-in object ACL operation in PutObject.

test.steps: Request the process on ensuring that PutObject requests on external bucket with bucket-owner-full-control ACL requirement but without S3 Object Ownership handover use 2 separate APIs

countermeasure.name: Prevent the creation of buckets with ACL enabled
countermeasure.desc:
Prevent the creation of buckets with ACL enabled (e.g. by using a SCP and/or an IAM policy on "s3:CreateBucket" with a deny statement on "s3:x-amz-object- ownership":"BucketOwnerEnforced").

Note it does not block someone to enable ACL afterwards via PutPutBucketOwnershipControls.

test.steps: Create a bucket to enable ACL, it should be denied.

countermeasure.name: Track all buckets you do not control that host your objects
countermeasure.desc: Track all buckets you don't control hosting your objects, define their authorised data classification, identify their respective owners (and AWS account ID), their ObjectACL requirements (including S3 Object Ownership), and get assured for the protection (e.g. through contractual agreement, verified by assurance programs, or using this ThreatModel).

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket
countermeasure.desc: Verify bucket ACL and object ACL are disabled on each bucket

test.steps: Create/modify a bucket to enable ACL, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify the control blocking change
countermeasure.desc: Verify the control blocking change ObjectACL to public (e.g. an SCP and VPC endpoint policy) is properly implemented

test.steps: Remove the control blocking changes of ObjectACL to public, it should be detected.

usecase.name: Object ACL must be explicitly denied

threat.name: Unauthorised modification of an object to become public or accessible in a private bucket you do not own by changing object ACL
threat.desc:
Bucket authority only prevails on object ACL when the object access is explicitly denied (ref). An attacker (or someone by negligence) can change the object ACL to make it public or accessible for themselves.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "s3:PutObjectAcl"

}

threat.name: Loss of ownership of an object
threat.desc: S3 Object Ownership enables a bucket receiver to convert a bucket-owner-full- control ACL into an ownership transfer (for new object); additionally a bucket can convert all the objects to be owned by the bucket owner. An attacker can modify the receiver bucket to remove your object ACL control on an object, and remove your access to this object.

component.name: AWS Services (with/without IAM)
component.desc: with IAM (eg CloudFront, CloudTrail, CM Logs) without IAM (eg Transcribe, Forecast, etc)

weakness.name: Limit access from only authorized VPCs
Threats on all AWS Services accessing S3 not quantified
weakness.desc: Many AWS Services access and utilise S3, you need to ensure that you understand the risk assocaited with these services and the buckets that they utilise

countermeasure.name: Aligned with your data governance
countermeasure.desc: Aligned with your data governance, encrypt on the client side - or tokenize - appropriate data

test.steps: Request the governance and mechanism(s) used to protect data (e.g. encrypt or tokenize critical data on the client side

countermeasure.name: Block PutObject requests with unauthorized KMS key on each bucket
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C61, assured by S3.C67]
Block PutObject requests with unauthorized KMS key on each bucket (e.g. using an S3 bucket policy deny statement on PutObject if the condition if exists "s3:x-amz-server-side- encryption-aws-kms-key-id" is not an authorized KMS key)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with an unauthorized KMS key, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Enforce AWS Services usage in VPC only (where possible)
countermeasure.desc: Enforce usage in VPC only, whenever possible.

countermeasure.name: Ensure all objects on S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C62]

Ensure all objects on S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key

test.steps: Request the mechanism (including training, or utility) ensuring only authorized KMS key are used for any objects stored in S3

countermeasure.name: For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, block PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C145, assured by S3.C147]
For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, block PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption (e.g. using an S3 bucket policy deny statement on PutObject if the condition "s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer- algorithm"="AES265" is not present)

test.steps: Make a request to a bucket (or path) requiring SSE-C without the proper encryption, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, monitor that only authorized encryption
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C145]


For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, monitor that only authorized encryption is used on each bucket or path (using CloudTrail S3 data events in requestParameter.bucketName and response.x-amz-server-side-encryption-customer- algorithm)

test.steps: Make a request to a bucket (or path) requiring SSE-C without the proper encryption, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, verify all buckets block PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption
countermeasure.desc: For buckets (or paths) requiring SSE-C, verify all buckets block PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption

test.steps: Create a bucket requiring SSE-C not blocking PutObject requests with unauthorized encryption, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: For each S3 bucket, maintain a list of VPC(s), authorized to access it.
countermeasure.desc: For each S3 bucket, maintain a list of VPC(s), authorized to access it.

test.steps: For each S3 bucket, request the list of authorized VPC to access it, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to authorised VPC
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C98, assured by S3.C100]
Limit the access to only those VPC(s) (e.g. using S3 bucket statement, deny if the condition "aws:SourceVpce", or if the bucket policy size is beyond the limit, use this condition on access point)

test.steps: Make a request to the bucket outside an authorized VPC, it should be denied

countermeasure.name: Limit the access to the IAM actions
countermeasure.desc: Limit the access to the IAM actions required to execute the threats using AWS IAM and/or SCP, following the IAM Operating Model and using the IAM ThreatModel. Use the IAM Access Advisor to review the usage of non-object-related S3 actions.

test.steps: Request the list of authorised IAM principals that have the permissions required to execute the threat actions, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of authorized KMS key(s) for each bucket,
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of authorized KMS key(s) for each bucket, and their default encryption key. You might simplify by using only 1 key per bucket, ideally dedicated. Note that S3 server access log bucket does not support KMS encryption (ref).

test.steps: Request the list of authorized KMS key(s) for each bucket, its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Maintain a list of buckets
countermeasure.desc: Maintain a list of buckets (or paths) required to be encrypted with server-side encryption with customer- provided keys (SSE-C)

test.steps: Request the list of buckets (or paths) required to be encrypted with server-side encryption with customer- provided keys (SSE-C), its review process, and its review records

countermeasure.name: Monitor that only authorized KMS key(s) are used on each bucket
countermeasure.desc:
[depends on S3.C61]
Monitor that only authorized KMS key(s) are used on each bucket (using CloudTrail S3 data events in requestParameter.bucketName and response.x-amz-server- side-encryption-aws-kms-key-id)

test.steps: Make a request encrypted with an unauthorized KMS key, it should be detected

countermeasure.name: Threat Model all AWS Services
countermeasure.desc: Analyse and protect all AWS services accessing S3 (e.g. via ThreatModel).

countermeasure.name: Use AWS IAM to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS Account
countermeasure.desc:
[assured by S3.C28]


In S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policy, do not allow IAM principals of the same AWS account. Only AWS IAM should be used to provide permissions to a principal of the same AWS account.

countermeasure.name: Verify all buckets block PutObject requests with an unauthorized KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Verify all buckets block PutObject requests with an unauthorized KMS key (e.g. using the Config rule: S3_BUCKET_POLICY_NOT_MORE_PERMISSIVE, note that a new rule needs be deployed for each configuration, then the resource tracked by name or tag; alternatively you might use S3_BUCKET_SERVER_SIDE_ENCRYPTION_ENABLED to ensure a limited coverage)

test.steps: Create a bucket not blocking PutObject requests with an unauthorized KMS key, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all buckets include a control to limit access to only authorized VPC(s)
countermeasure.desc: Verify all buckets include a control to limit access to only authorized VPC(s) (e.g. using the AWS Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK)

test.steps: Remove the control limiting access to only authorized VPC(s), it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all objects on S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key
countermeasure.desc: Verify all objects on S3 buckets are encrypted with an authorized KMS key (e.g. using S3 inventory, see blog, or S3 Storage Lens)

test.steps: Upload an encrypted data using an unauthorized KMS key, it should be detected.

countermeasure.name: Verify all S3 Bucket/Access Point/Object Lambda access point policies
countermeasure.desc: Verify all S3 bucket/access point/Object Lambda access point policies do not allow an IAM principal of the same AWS account (e.g. using the Config rule S3_BUCKET_POLICY_GRANTEE_CHECK for bucket policy)

test.steps:
Add an allow statement for an IAM principal of the same account in

  1. a bucket policy
  2. in an access point policy
  3. in an Object Lambda access point
it should be detected.

usecase.name: AWS Services access S3 to execute own functions

threat.name: Use AWS services to access data on S3
threat.desc:
Number of AWS services can access S3 to execute their own functions. An attacker can use them to collect data, using their service role or service-linked roles.

IAM Access

{

"UNIQUE": "iam:PassRole"

}
